p: Influenza viruses are considered to be a major human health problem with a global distribution, with considerable impact on the quality of life and productivity of the society. An estimated of more than 290,000 seasonal influenza-associated respiratory deaths annually occur worldwide [ 1]. In the American region, each year, an average of 772,000 respiratory hospitalizations is attributed to influenza virus [ 2]. Although influenza A viruses (IAV) are responsible for pandemics and they have major rates of hospitalization and mortality attribution, influenza B viruses (IBV) cause epidemics worldwide annually, becoming responsible in some years for more than 25% of human seasonal influenza infections, and its prevention represents an important public health priority [ 3, 4, 5]. In vaccine mismatch seasons, hospitalization due to IBV can exceed IAV in all age groups, particularly among children and young teenagers [ 6].
